question: Public Interest Litigation (PIL) in India is mainly based on which constitutional provisions?
statements: Article 32 deals with the right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights
Article 226 empowers High Courts to issue writs
PIL was created through a constitutional amendment
explanation: PIL developed through Supreme Court judgments, not through any constitutional amendment. It rests mainly on Article 32 and Article 226 enabling writ jurisdiction. For background, see [[Article 32]] and [[Article 226]].

question: Consider the following statements about the evolution of Public Interest Litigation (PIL) in India:
statements: It was formally recognised in the S.P. Gupta case
Early PILs focused primarily on prisoners, bonded labourers and undertrials
PILs began only after the 1990s reforms
explanation: PIL emerged in late 1970s and 1980s through cases such as Hussainara Khatoon and S.P. Gupta. It did not start after 1990s. Refer to [[Hussainara Khatoon v. State of Bihar]] and [[S.P. Gupta v. Union of India]].

question: Which of the following is NOT an area where Public Interest Litigation is usually entertained?
explanation: PIL is not permitted in personal service disputes. Courts accept PILs mainly in matters related to environment, human rights, governance failures. See [[Public Interest Litigation in India]].

question: Which of the following features are associated with PIL in India?
statements: Letter petitions are accepted by courts
Courts may appoint expert committees for fact-finding
explanation: All three are core features of PIL and part of judge-made procedures developed since the 1980s. The Supreme Court often uses continuing mandamus and fact-finding teams. Refer to [[Judiciary of India]].

question: The National Judicial Appointments Commission (NJAC) sought to replace the Collegium system. Which of the following were members of the NJAC?
statements: Two eminent persons selected by a three-member committee
explanation: All three were part of the NJAC composition under the 99th Constitutional Amendment. See [[National Judicial Appointments Commission]].

question: Why was the National Judicial Appointments Commission (NJAC) struck down by the Supreme Court?
options: It violated the basic structure doctrine
It reduced Parliament’s powers of oversight
It granted excessive powers to the CAG
correct_option: It violated the basic structure doctrine
explanation: The Court held that judicial independence is part of the basic structure, and executive/civil influence in appointments would compromise it. See [[Basic structure doctrine]].

question: Which of the following reforms are part of India’s ongoing judicial reforms?
statements: E-courts project for digital case management
Gram Nyayalayas for improving rural access to justice
explanation: All three are officially recognised reform measures. E-courts, judicial manpower expansion and Gram Nyayalayas are part of institutional reforms. See [[E-Courts Project]].

question: Which case is associated with the judicial creation of the Collegium system?
explanation: The Collegium system came from the Second Judges Case (1993) and was refined in the Third Judges Case (1998). Refer to [[Supreme Court of India]].

question: Which of the following correctly describes the Memorandum of Procedure (MoP) in judicial appointments?
statements: It lays down the process for appointing judges to the higher judiciary
It is prepared by the Government but finalised in consultation with the Supreme Court
It is explicitly mentioned in the Constitution
explanation: MoP is an executive document, not mentioned in the Constitution. It guides the appointments process after the NJAC verdict. See [[Collegium system in India]].

question: Which of the following best explains the purpose of PIL in India?
options: To allow courts to review legislative bills before passing
To provide access to justice for those unable to approach courts
To reduce the number of civil cases
To grant advisory opinions to NGOs
correct_option: To provide access to justice for those unable to approach courts
explanation: The core objective of PIL is social justice—ensuring the poor, vulnerable and marginalised can seek remedies through courts. See [[Public Interest Litigation in India]].

question: Which case is associated with recognition of the right to legal aid under PIL?
explanation: The Hussainara Khatoon case expanded the right to legal aid and speedy trial using PIL. It was a major step towards Article 21 jurisprudence. See [[Hussainara Khatoon v. State of Bihar]].

question: In India, PIL can be initiated by which of the following?
statements: The court on its own motion
explanation: Courts accept PIL filed by public-spirited individuals and also through suo motu actions. Only affected persons are NOT the sole category. Refer to [[Public Interest Litigation in India]].

question: Which of the following measures help reduce pendency in Indian courts?
explanation: All three are key reforms promoted by the judiciary and government to reduce delays. See [[Fast-track court]] and [[Alternative dispute resolution in India]].

question: Which provision empowers the Supreme Court to issue writs for enforcement of Fundamental Rights?
explanation: Article 32 is known as the heart and soul of the Constitution and forms the basis of PIL in the Supreme Court. See [[Article 32]].

question: Which of the following criticisms are often made about the Collegium system?
statements: Excessive control of the executive in appointments
explanation: The Collegium is criticised for secrecy and possible favouritism, but not for excessive executive control. See [[Collegium system in India]].

question: Which judge gave the famous dissenting opinion in the NJAC judgment?
explanation: Justice J. Chelameswar dissented and highlighted opacity in the collegium system. Refer to [[Supreme Court Advocates-on-Record Association v. Union of India]].

question: Which of the following are considered advantages of PIL in India?
statements: It promotes citizen participation in governance
It compels the government to perform its duties
It allows courts to hear private property disputes
explanation: PIL strengthens accountability and democratic participation, but private property disputes cannot be brought under PIL. See [[Public Interest Litigation in India]].

question: Which reform is linked to improving access to justice for rural and poor citizens?
explanation: The Gram Nyayalayas Act aims at quick, affordable justice at the village level. Refer to [[Gram Nyayalayas Act, 2008]].

question: Which of the following correctly identifies a type of PIL?
explanation: Epistolary jurisdiction allows letter petitions; service matters are excluded from PIL jurisdiction. See [[Public Interest Litigation in India]].

question: Which administrative reform aims at transparency in judicial appointments after the NJAC verdict?
explanation: After NJAC was struck down, the Supreme Court asked the Government to draft a new MoP to improve transparency in the collegium system. See [[Collegium system in India]].

question: Which of the following best describes the concept of 'continuing mandamus' used in PIL?
statements: It allows courts to keep a case open for monitoring
It empowers courts to supervise implementation of directions
It is a special writ issued only to the President
explanation: Continuing mandamus is used in PILs to ensure continuous judicial monitoring of government compliance. See [[Mandamus]].

question: Which of the following committees or bodies are linked to judicial reforms in India?
explanation: Judicial reforms are led by bodies like the Law Commission and NCMS; NCRB deals with crime statistics. See [[Law Commission of India]].

question: Which of the following are considered causes of pendency in Indian courts?
explanation: All three factors contribute to pendency across courts. See [[Judiciary of India]].

question: Which landmark case expanded Article 21 to include the right to livelihood?
explanation: The Supreme Court held that the right to livelihood is part of Article 21. See [[Olga Tellis v. Bombay Municipal Corporation]].

question: Which of the following are grounds on which the Supreme Court struck down the NJAC?
statements: Possibility of political influence through eminent persons
explanation: The Court held that executive and outsider presence may lead to political pressure, violating independence. Federalism was not a ground. See [[National Judicial Appointments Commission]].

question: Which of the following are examples of social justice PILs?
explanation: Early PILs focused on bonded labourers and prisoners; property disputes are excluded. See [[Public Interest Litigation in India]].

question: Which of the following correctly identifies the type of jurisdiction used by courts in PIL?
explanation: PIL mainly uses writ jurisdiction under Articles 32 and 226. See [[Writ]].

question: Which of the following reforms is aimed at reducing judge–vacancy gaps?
explanation: AIJS is proposed to create a uniform recruitment system for subordinate judges. See [[All India Judicial Service]].

question: In which case did the Supreme Court introduce the 'basic structure' doctrine, later used to strike down the NJAC?
explanation: The basic structure doctrine originated in this 1973 judgment. See [[Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala]].

question: Which of the following best represents a misuse of PIL?
options: Court-initiated suo motu action during a disaster
explanation: Frivolous or publicity-motivated PILs burden courts and divert attention from genuine causes. See [[Public Interest Litigation in India]].
